type: Historic District and Former Austrian Town
description: Zemun is a historic district of Belgrade that was once a separate town on the border of the Austrian Empire. It features distinct Central European architecture and character that remain strikingly different from Byzantine-influenced Belgrade, along with the famous Gardoš Tower and the scenic Zemun Kej promenade.

history.austrian_period: Habsburg Austrian armies took over Zemun in 1717 and stayed for two centuries
history.strategic_importance: Zemun grew as a border town in a highly strategic position next to the Ottomans' northern fortress of Belgrade, serving as a key port and assembly point for smugglers, rebels, insurgents, spies and politicians
history.integration: Eventually absorbed by Belgrade but still fights to preserve its distinct identity
history.character: Central European architecture and character remain strikingly different from Byzantine neighbor Belgrade

gardos_tower.purpose: Built to celebrate a thousand years of Hungarian settlement in the Pannonian plain
gardos_tower.location: Built on the ruins of the medieval fortress Taurunum on Gardoš hill
gardos_tower.significance: Being the southernmost city in then Hungary within Austria-Hungary
gardos_tower.history: Severely damaged in 1914 during Austrian-Serbian fighting in World War I, but was renovated during the Interbellum

zemun_kej.description: Kilometers long promenade along the bank of the Danube
attractions: Hotel Jugoslavija (formerly largest hotel in Belgrade)
zemun_kej.wildlife: Main attraction for several years has been swans who have found a quiet place for life
zemun_kej.atmosphere: Relaxed waterfront setting popular for walks and dining

characteristics.architecture: Central European style distinct from rest of Belgrade
characteristics.atmosphere: Small-town feel within the big city
characteristics.views: Offers views from Gardoš Hill across the Danube

visitor_experience.atmosphere: More relaxed and European compared to busy Belgrade center
visitor_experience.best_for: Escaping city crowds while remaining within Belgrade

interesting_facts: Under Austrian rule for two centuries (1717-1918)
Gardoš Tower celebrates 1000 years of Hungarian settlement
Served as border town between Austrian and Ottoman Empires
Built on site of ancient Roman fortress Taurunum
Famous for swans that live along the Danube promenade
Preserves unique Central European character within Belgrade
